output:
The remote HTTPS server does not send the HTTP
  "Strict-Transport-Security" header.

definition.name: HSTS Missing From HTTPS Server (RFC 6797)
definition.description: The remote web server is not enforcing HSTS, as defined by RFC 6797. HSTS is an optional response header that can be configured on the server to instruct the browser to only communicate via HTTPS. The lack of HSTS allows downgrade attacks, SSL-stripping man-in-the-middle attacks, and weakens cookie-hijacking protections.
definition.solution: Configure the remote web server to use HSTS.
definition.synopsis: The remote web server is not enforcing HSTS, as defined by RFC 6797.
definition.output:
The remote HTTPS server does not send the HTTP
  "Strict-Transport-Security" header.

output: TLSv1.1 is enabled and the server supports at least one cipher.

definition.name: TLS Version 1.1 Protocol Deprecated
definition.description:
The remote service accepts connections encrypted using TLS 1.1. TLS 1.1 lacks support for current and recommended cipher suites. Ciphers that support encryption before MAC computation, and authenticated encryption modes such as GCM cannot be used with TLS 1.1

As of March 31, 2020, Endpoints that are not enabled for TLS 1.2 and higher will no longer function properly with major web browsers and major vendors.
definition.solution: Enable support for TLS 1.2 and/or 1.3, and disable support for TLS 1.1.
definition.synopsis: The remote service encrypts traffic using an older version of TLS.
definition.output: TLSv1.1 is enabled and the server supports at least one cipher.

definition.name: SSL RC4 Cipher Suites Supported (Bar Mitzvah)
definition.description:
The remote host supports the use of RC4 in one or more cipher suites.
The RC4 cipher is flawed in its generation of a pseudo-random stream of bytes so that a wide variety of small biases are introduced into the stream, decreasing its randomness.

If plaintext is repeatedly encrypted (e.g., HTTP cookies), and an attacker is able to obtain many (i.e., tens of millions) ciphertexts, the attacker may be able to derive the plaintext.
definition.solution: Reconfigure the affected application, if possible, to avoid use of RC4 ciphers. Consider using TLS 1.2 with AES-GCM suites subject to browser and web server support.
definition.synopsis: The remote service supports the use of the RC4 cipher.

output: TLSv1.1 is enabled and the server supports at least one cipher.

definition.name: TLS Version 1.1 Protocol Deprecated
definition.description:
The remote service accepts connections encrypted using TLS 1.1. TLS 1.1 lacks support for current and recommended cipher suites. Ciphers that support encryption before MAC computation, and authenticated encryption modes such as GCM cannot be used with TLS 1.1

As of March 31, 2020, Endpoints that are not enabled for TLS 1.2 and higher will no longer function properly with major web browsers and major vendors.
definition.solution: Enable support for TLS 1.2 and/or 1.3, and disable support for TLS 1.1.
definition.synopsis: The remote service encrypts traffic using an older version of TLS.
definition.output: TLSv1.1 is enabled and the server supports at least one cipher.

output:
The server is not configured to return a custom page in the event of a client requesting a non-existent resource.
This may result in a potential disclosure of sensitive information about the server to attackers.

definition.name: Apache Tomcat Default Files
definition.description: The default error page, default index page, example JSPs and/or example servlets are installed on the remote Apache Tomcat server. These files should be removed as they may help an attacker uncover information about the remote Tomcat install or host itself.
definition.solution: Delete the default index page and remove the example JSP and servlets. Follow the Tomcat or OWASP instructions to replace or modify the default error page.
definition.synopsis: The remote web server contains default files.
definition.output:
The server is not configured to return a custom page in the event of a client requesting a non-existent resource.
This may result in a potential disclosure of sensitive information about the server to attackers.
